Implementation of that creates a single default test collection for the assembly, and places any tests classes which are not decorated by or into the default test collection.
Implementation of which creates a new test collection for each test class that isn't decorated with or .
Base class for all execution pipeline context classes.
Abstract attribute which represents a based implementation of . Data source providers derive from this attribute and implement to return the data for the theory.
Default implementation of . Orders tests in an unpredictable but stable order, so that repeated test runs of the identical test assembly run tests in the same order.
Default implementation of . Orders tests in an unpredictable and unstable order, so that repeated test runs of the identical test assembly run test collections in a random order.
Implementation of that delegates to another implementation of while calling into an optional callback for each message.

Implementation of that delegates to another implementation of while calling into an optional callback for each message. In addition, it issues a event when a message of the type TFinalMessage is seen and records the final message for later retrieval.
Implementation of that delegates to another implementation of while calling into an optional callback for each message.

Implementation of that delegates to another implementation of while calling into an optional callback for each message. In addition, it issues a event when a message of the type TFinalMessage is seen and records the final message for later retrieval.
Default implementation of .
Default implementation of .
Default implementation of .
Represents a formatter that formats the display name of a class and/or method into a more human readable form using additional options.
Container class for token used to dynamically skip tests.
Default implementation of .
Aggregates exceptions. Intended to run one or more code blocks, and collect the exceptions thrown by those code blocks.
A simple implementation of that can be used to report an error rather than running a test.
The methods on this static class can measure the time taken to execute actions (both synchronous and asynchronous).
Represents a factory for the types used for extensibility throughout the system.
Implementation of that supports finding test cases on methods decorated with .
Maps fixture objects, including support for generic collection fixtures.

Used to decorate xUnit.net test assemblies to indicate per-assembly fixture data. An instance of the fixture data is initialized before any test in the assembly are run (including if it's implemented). After all the tests in the assembly have been run, it is cleaned up by calling if it's implemented, or it falls back to if that's implemented. Assembly fixtures must have a public parameterless constructor. To gain access to the fixture data from inside the test, a constructor argument should be added to the test class which exactly matches the fixture type.
Indicates an attribute which is involved in test method interception (allows code to be run before and after a test is run).
Used to declare a specific test collection for a test class. Only valid on test classes, and only a single instance of a collection attribute may be present.
Used to declare the default test collection behavior for the assembly. This is only valid at the assembly level, and there can be only one.
Base interface that all data attributes (that is, data providers for theories) are expected to implement. Data attributes are valid on methods only.

Attribute that is applied to a method to indicate that it is a test method that should be run by the default test runner. Implementations must be decorated by to indicate which class is responsible for converting the test method into one or more tests.
Used by discovery, execution, and extensibility code to send messages to the runner.
Represents an implementation of that is self-executing. This allows the test case to opt into the middle of the test execution pipeline without implementing everything that comes before it.

A class implements this interface to participate in ordering tests for the test runner. Test case orderers are applied using an implementation of (most commonly ), which can be applied at the assembly, test collection, and test class level.
Used to decorate an assembly, test collection, or test class to allow the use of a custom test case orderer. Only one may exist on a given element.

A class implements this interface to participate in ordering tests for the test runner. Test collection orderers are applied using the and implementation of (most commonly ), which can be applied at the assembly level.
Used to decorate an assembly, test collection, or test class to allow the use of a custom test collection orderer. Only one may exist on a given element.

Represents a test framework. There are two pieces to test frameworks: discovery and execution. The two factory methods represent these two pieces. Test frameworks may optionally implement either or . They may implement a constructor which is either empty, or takes a single for diagnostic messages, or takes two instances of for diagnostic messages and internal diagnostic messages, respectively.
Used to decorate an assembly to allow the use of a custom test framework. May only be placed at the assembly level, and only a single test framework is allowed.
Represents an implementation of the discovery part of a test framework. Implementations may optionally implement and/or for cleanup operations.
Represents an implementation of the execution part of a test framework. Implementations may optionally implement and/or for cleanup operations.
Interface implemented by developers who want to run code during test pipeline startup and shutdown. A single instance of this may be decorated with an instance of (typically ) at the assembly level.
Used to decorate xUnit.net test assemblies to indicate that the developer wishes to have code that runs during the test pipeline startup and shutdown (including both discovery and execution).
This is a marker interface implemented to indicate that the exception is the result of a test timeout, resulting in a failure cause of .

Marks a test method as being a data theory. Data theories are tests which are fed various bits of data from a data source, mapping to parameters on the test method. If the data source contains multiple rows, then the test method is executed multiple times (once with each data row). Data is provided by attributes which implement (most commonly, and ). Implementations must be decorated by to indicate which class is responsible for converting the test method into one or more tests.
Base interface that all traits attributes (that is, anything with provides traits to a test). Trait attributes are valid on assemblies, classes, and methods.
Indicates a test case which delays enumeration of tests until execution time.
Represents a test from xUnit.net v3 based on reflection.
Represents a test assembly from xUnit.net v3 based on reflection.
Represents a single test case from xUnit.net v3 based on reflection.
Interface to be implemented by classes which are used to discover tests cases attached to test methods that are attributed with an implementation of .
Represents a test class from xUnit.net v3 based on reflection.
Represents a test collection from xUnit.net v3 based on reflection.

This interface is intended to be implemented by components which generate test collections. End users specify the desired test collection factory by applying (or any attribute that implements ) at the assembly level. Classes which implement this interface must have a constructor that takes .
Represents a test class from xUnit.net v3 based on reflection.

This class is a "philosophical" implementation of (which isn't a type that's available here), intended to be used by in-process runners, wrapped around an implementation of . The signatures of the methods are slightly different, as they permit and require direct access to instances rather than forcing the test cases through a round of serialization and deserialization. It will also manufacture the and messages that the test framework is not responsible for. When connected to remote meta-runners, the in-process runner can convert instances into instances by using a converter like (which should be called from a callback passed to ).
Default implementation of .
An implementation of which runs work on custom threads rather than in the thread pool, and limits the number of in-flight actions.
Provides a base class for attributes that will provide member data.
Default implementation of , with serialization support.
Represents the statistical summary from a run of one or more tests.

A default implementation of that tracks objects to be disposed when the framework is disposed. The discoverer and executor are automatically tracked for disposal, since those interfaces mandate an implementation of .
